about.label: AMAC Advanced Example 2: Bimodal excitation of a Biolever in a liquid environment
Choose excitation source
about.description: Choose the source by which the cantilever is excited. This may be imporant for low quality factors.

about.label: Choose frequency scheme
about.description: Choose the number of frequencies in the drive (excitation) signal.

about.label: Number of eigenmodes
about.description: Number of eigenmodes (vibrational modes) to be included in the simulation. You will need one comma separated value for each ki, Qi, and fi for EACH eigenmode!

about.label: Self-excitation gain
about.description: Self-excitation gain. (no units)

about.label: Self-excitation saturation
about.description: Self-excitation saturation (no units)

about.label: Self-excitation phase delay (degrees)
about.description: Phase delay (implemented as a time relative to the first natural frequency). This a phase lag between 0 and 360 degree. Values > 180 can be interpreted as a lead. E.g. 270 deg lag is same as 90 deg lead.

about.label: Direct Input of Base Amp / Mag Forces
about.description: If this box is checked, you can enter the base excitation amplitude (acoustic drive) or magnetic modal forces (magnetic drive) directly. If it is unchecked (the default) then these parameters are automatically calculated corresponding to the specified unconstrained amplitude. Most users will want to use the default

about.label: Direct input
about.description: Directly enter the base amplitude (nm) for acoustic excitation, or comma separated list of modal forces for magnetic excitation. For acoustic bimodal enter comma separated list; magnetic bimodal is not supported here. Most users will want to uncheck the above box and enter the tip amplitude instead

about.label: Unconstrained Amplitude (nm)
about.description: The unconstrained amplitude at the first (or only) excitation frequency far from the sample surface in the absence of tip-sample interaction forces.

about.label: Unconstrained Amplitude (2nd drive frq) (nm)
about.description: The unconstrained amplitude at the second (bimodal) excitation frequency far from the sample surface in the absence of tip-sample interaction forces.

about.label: Auto calculate stiffnesses k_i (i>1)?
about.description: To input k2, k3, etc., leave the box unchecked. To auto calculated k2, k3, etc based on k1, check the box. Auto calculation is valid only for rectangular diving board cantilevers

about.label: Cantilever stiffness k_i (N/m)
about.description: Enter comma separated values for the equivalent stiffness of each eigenmode.

about.label: Q
about.description: Enter comma separated values of the quality factors or each eigenmode. We define quality factor as 1/(2*damping ratio).

about.label: Auto calculate omega_i (i>1)?
about.description: To input omega2, omega3, etc., leave the box unchecked. To allow the omega_i's to be calculated (for i > 1), check the box. Autocalculation is valid only for rectangular diving board cantilevers

about.label: fi (kHz)
about.description: Enter comma separated values for the natural frequencies of each eigenmode.

about.label: fd (kHz)
about.description: The excitation frequency applied to the cantilever. Enter comma separated values for each excitation frequency (1 for conventional, 2 for bimodal)

about.label: Tip mass
about.description: Tip mass as a fraction of the cantilever beam mass.

about.label: Z approach velocity (nm/s)
about.description: The average speed that the base of the cantilever approaches the sample.

about.label: gamma (Z drag)
about.description: The drag coefficient (kg/s)

about.label: Z range determination
about.description: The autocalculated default Z range is Z0 = 5nm greater than the unconstrained amplitude and Zf = zero. You can also manually enter a Z range, or enter a setpoint to stop at.

about.label: Approach to specified setpoint (does not work for retract)
Initial Z separation (nm)
about.description: The initial gap between the sample and the base of the cantilever. Note: this is not the tip-sample gap. Any static deflection due to long range forces is added (or subtracted) to this value to get the initial tip-sample gap.

about.label: Final Z separation (nm)
about.description: The final gap between the sample and the base of the cantilever.

about.label: Final setpoint ratio
about.description: The final gap between the sample and the base of the cantilever.

about.label: Choose Lock-In Filter Order
about.description: Lock In Filter order

about.label: None
about.description: Do not use a lock in

about.label: 1st order (20 dB/decade)
about.description: 1st order Butterworth filter (20 dB/decade or 6 dB/octave)

about.label: 2nd order (40 dB/decade)
about.description: 2nd order Butterworth filter (40 dB/decade or 12 dB/octave)

about.label: 4th order (80 dB/decade)
about.description: 4th order Butterworth filter (80 dB/decade or 24 dB/octave)

about.label: Auto-Calculate Time constant
about.description: Automatically calculates the time constant required for the simulation

about.label: Lock-in time constant
about.description: The amplitude feedback parameter is determined by a filter with this time constant in microseconds. Note the controller performance is affected by Lock-in time constant so if you change time-constant you may need to change the gains as well. Note: versions of VEDA prior to October 22, 2010 had a bug in the calculation of lock-in time constant. If you are trying to match a previous simulation, you will need to choose a time constant that is approximately a factor of 5 larger than what you used previously (i.e. 5 times smaller bandwidth)

note.contents: (Note: use scroll bar on right to access more choices below)

about.label: Slope Calibration 1 - Slope Calibration n
about.description: Enter comma separated values for Slope Calibration (Chi) values starting with the 1st eigenmode.

about.label: Auto calculate alpha_i
about.description: To input alpha directly uncheck the box. To allow the alpha_i's to be calculated, leave the box checked. If you are unsure, leave the box checked.

about.label: alpha
about.description: Enter comma separated values for the dispersion alpha of each eigenmode.

about.label: Include Fluid borne loading
about.description: When this box is checked you can enter fluid borne loading (see Xu and Raman JAP 2007, vol 102)

about.label: Afluid real part
about.description: The real (inertial) part of the fluid borne loading

about.label: Afluid imag part
about.description: The imaginary (viscous) part of the fluid borne loading

about.label: m* / mc
about.description: The ratio of added fluid mass to cantilever mass

about.label: Tip-sample interaction model
about.description: Choose a model to predict the forces exterted by the tip on the sample.

about.label: Linear contact
about.description: Interaction forces are predicted according to a (piece-wise) linear contact model for an overall stiffness, kts, of the sample.

about.label: Linear attractive/repulsive
about.description: Interaction forces are predicted according to a (piece-wise) linear contact model for an overall stiffness, kts_r, of the sample, and an attractive-force gradient, kts_a.

about.label: Hertz contact
about.description: Hertz contact model with no attractive forces.

about.label: DMT contact
about.description: Derjaguin-Muller-Toporov (DMT) contact model including van der Waals attractive forces. This model was the only choice available in the previous version of VEDA

about.label: DMT + DLVO interactions (liquids)
about.description: Derjaguin-Muller-Toporov + Derjaguin-Landau-Verwey-Overbeek (electrical double layer) interaction forces.

about.label: JKR
about.description: Johnson-Kendall-Roberts interaction forces.

about.label: Chadwick
about.description: Chadwick interaction model for a thin membrane loosely bound to a stiff substrate.

about.label: Van der Waals + Morse Potential
about.description: Morse potential is used in non-contact FM-AFM to model bonding interation. Should NOT be used for AM-AFM in tapping mode, or in any repulsive regime.

about.label: Van der Waals + Lennard Jones Potential
about.description: Lennard Jones potential is used in non-contact FM-AFM to model attractive regime. Should NOT be used for AM-AFM in tapping mode, or in any repulsive regime.

about.label: Electrostatic Forces (noncontact), Gil et al. + van der Waals
Magnetic dipole-dipole (sphere-sphere, Rasa et al)
about.description: This is the sphere-sphere model equation 6 from M. Ra≈üa, B.W.M. Kuipers, P. Philipse, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science 2002, 250, 303-15.

about.label: Custom MD simulation (BETA test - not ready for general use)
about.description: Input of data interpolated from molecular dynamic simulations. Do not use unless you know what you are doing.

about.label: Tip radius (nm)
about.description: Radius of the probe tip.

about.enable: input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 13 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 10 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 9 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 8 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 1 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 6 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 11 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 16 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 17
about.label: Young's modulus of tip (GPa)

about.enable: input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 13 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 10 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 9 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 8 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 1 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 6 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 11 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 16 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 17
about.label: Poisson's ratio of the tip
Sample stiffness (N/m)
about.description: Effective stiffness of the tip-sample contact.

about.label: Attractive force gradient (N/m)
about.description: Effective attractive force gradient as the cantilever tip approaches the sample.

about.label: Auto Calculate intermolecular distance?
about.description: Check this box to automatically calculate the intermolecular distance in the DMT model from the adhesion force, the tip radius and the Hamaker constant (this was the default in the original version). This is most useful for matching to a single experiment. Uncheck this box to enter the intermolecular distance directly. This is most useful for parameter studies

about.label: van der Waals Adhesion force (nN)
about.description: The adhesion force is the attractive force applied on the cantilever tip by the sample by van der Waals forces just before contact, neglecting any capillary forces. Capillary force contributions to adhesion are described seperately below

about.label: Intermolecular distance (nm)
about.description: The intermolecular distance required for the Derjaguin-Muller-Toporov (DMT contact model)

about.label: Hamaker constant (J)
about.description: The Hamaker constant is used to predict attractive van der Waals forces and depends on the material of the tip, the sample, and the surrounding media.

about.enable: input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 13 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 10 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 9 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 1 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 8 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 6 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 11 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 16 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 17
about.label: Young's modulus of sample (GPa)

about.enable: input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 13 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 10 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 9 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 1 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 6 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 8 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 11 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 16 && input.phase(ts).choice(fts_model) != 17
about.label: Poisson's ratio of the sample
Debye length (um)
about.description: The Debye length of the liquid. This is ~1 um for deionized water, ~0.001 um for 100 mM of 1:1 electrolyte

about.label: Imaging media Dielectric constant
about.description: Dielectric constant of the imaging media (air ~= 1, water ~= 80)

about.label: Surface charge density (tip) (C/m^2)
about.description: Surface charge density

about.label: Surface charge density (sample) (C/m^2)
about.description: Surface charge density

about.label: Membrane thickness (nm)
about.description: The thickness of a membrane loosely bound to the sample surface.

about.label: Morse equilibrium position (nm)
about.description: Morse equilibrium position (nm)

about.label: Morse range (nm)
about.description: Morse range (nm)

about.label: Morse depth (J)
about.description: Morse depth (J)

about.label: LJ equilibrium position (nm)
about.description: Lennard Jones equilibrium position (nm)

about.label: LJ binding energy (J)
about.description: Lennard Jones binding (J)

about.label: Effective magnetic dia of sample particle (nm)
L0 (nm)
about.description: L0

about.label: Lp (nm)
about.description: Lp

about.label: Rupture force (nN)
about.description: The chain will rupture at this force

about.label: Temperature (K)
about.description: Temperature in kelvin

about.label: Sigma (nm)
about.description: Period and Decay length of the oscillatory forces

about.label: Rho
about.description: Number density of the liquid (1/m^3)

about.label: Lambda (nm)
about.description: Decay length of the Hydration force

about.label: Hydration scaling
about.description: Strength of Hydration force (empirically determined constant). Called p_h by Jeffery et al

about.label: Rtip solvation (nm)
about.description: Effective tip radius for solvation shells. Note this may be different than the effective tip radius above

about.label: Number slices
about.description: Number of slices for discretization of tip. N=1 (recommended) gives a simple exponentially decaying cosine for the oscillatory forces and a exponential decay for hydration force.

about.label: Enforce continuous gradient
about.description: If this is unchecked, then the solvation forces saturate at d=0. If this is checked, then the solvation forces continue past d=0, which enforces a continuous gradient.

about.label: Non-conservative solvation forces (hysteretic)
about.description: This models the non-conservative component of solvation forces as hysteretic force using the model proposed in Vo√Øtchovsky et al.

about.label: Non-conservative solvation forces (viscous)
about.description: This models the non-conservative component of solvation forces as a viscosity that decays exponentially away from the surface. Note: Jeffery proposed that damping was proportional to stiffness, which includes oscillatory forces, but we model only a monotonic damping coefficient.

about.label: Scaling (kg/s)
about.description: Damping coefficient kg/s=N-s/m at Z=0

about.label: Decay (nm)
about.description: Decay length. Typically this should be on the order of the molecular diameter (e.g. 0.2 - 0.3 for water)

about.label: Preisach
about.description: Beta testing. Don't use.

about.label: Tip-Sample Squeeze Film Damping
about.description: Beta testing. Don't use.

about.label: Viscosity (Pa-s)
about.description: Liquid viscosity

about.label: Include sample visco-elastic forces?
about.description: Select the model for visco-elastic damping. The tip is assumed to be rigid if visoelastic forces are included.

about.label: None
about.description: No visco-elastic forces

about.label: Ad-hoc Kelvin-Voigt
about.description: This is the only viscoelastic model currently supported in conjunction with attractive forces. See the manual for more details.

about.label: Include sample visco-elastic forces?
about.description: Select the model for visco-elastic damping. The tip is assumed to be rigid if visoelastic forces are included.

about.label: None
about.description: No visco-elastic forces

about.label: Kelvin-Voigt
about.description: The kelvin-voigt model is a spring and a damper (dashpot) in parallel

about.label: Three element model
about.description: The standard three element model is a spring in series with a Kelvin-voigt element. This is the simplest model that captures the typical features of viscoelastic solids

about.label: Ad-hoc Kelvin-Voigt (not recommended)
about.description: This is the model used in previous versions of VEDA, and most previous literature. Use only for comparing to prior work. Not recommended for new simulations.

about.label: Include sample visco-elastic forces?
about.description: Select the model for visco-elastic damping. The tip is assumed to be rigid if visoelastic forces are included.

about.label: None
about.description: No visco-elastic forces

about.label: Kelvin-Voigt
about.description: The kelvin-voigt model is a spring and a damper (dashpot) in parallel

about.label: Three element model
about.description: The standard three element model is a spring in series with a Kelvin-voigt element. This is the simplest model that captures the typical features of viscoelastic solids

about.label: Maxwell
about.description: The Maxwell model is a spring and a damper (dashpot) in series. This is suitable for viscoelastic liquids. It describes solids only if the viscosity is very large.

about.label: Generalized Maxwell (Prony series)
about.description: A number of Maxwell elements in parallel. The modulus entered as sample youngs modulus above is E_infinity.

about.label: Ad-hoc Kelvin-Voigt (not recommended)
about.description: This is the model used in previous versions of VEDA, and most previous literature. Use only for comparing to prior work. Not recommended for new simulations.

about.label: E2 modulus (GPa)
about.description: For the three element model, the sample Youngs modulus above is E1 and you enter E2 here (see manual for description of which is E1 and E2.

about.label: Sample viscosity (Pa-s)
about.description: Enter a value for the sample viscosity.

about.label: Number of elements for Generalized Maxwell
about.description: Enter the number of elements in the Generalized Maxwell (prony series) model. You may enter up to 99 elements

about.label: Generalized Maxwell Youngs modulii (GPa)
about.description: Enter a comma separated list of the youngs modulii for the generalized maxwell model. In addition to these elements, the sample youngs modulus above counts as one element with an infinite relaxation time.

about.label: Generalized Maxwell relaxation times (s)
about.description: Enter a comma separated list of the relaxation times for the generalized maxwell model.

about.label: Sample viscosity (Pa-s)
about.description: Enter a value for the sample viscosity.

about.label: Damping coefficient (N-s/m)
about.description: Enter a viscoelasticity damping coefficient in N-s/m.

about.label: k2 Stiffness (N/m)
about.description: Enter the k2 stiffness for the three element model (the number above for sample stiffness is k1). see manual for which is k1 and which is k2.

about.label: Include capillary forces?
about.description:
To include surface hysteretic force components, select "yes." This adhesion hysteresis model was taken from Kober et al, Rapid Research Letters, 2008.
Checking or unchecking this box changes the figure at the top of the page. Scroll up to see the updated diagram.
Capillary forces cannot be used with JRK or DMT+DLVO models at present. Capillary forces can not be applied to Morse or Lennard Jones potential models.
NOTE: if you receive a DDASKR error, try increasing the number of deflection points per cycle, or decrease the approach velocity.

about.label: Critical gap, D_0 (nm)
about.description: The breaking gap at which the hysteretic force component goes to zero.

about.label: Energy dissipated, dE (eV)
about.description: The energy dissipated in the contact process during each cycle to the hysteretic force component.

about.label: Number of points plotted
about.description: The number of data points plotted/saved.

about.label: Deflection points per cycle
about.description: Number of points calculated per oscillation cycle. NOTE: if you receive a DDASKR error, try increasing this number.

about.label: Plot a higher harmonic?
about.description: To plot a higher harmonic of the excitation frequency of the delfection waveform, select "yes."

about.label: Number of higher harmonics
about.description: Enter the number of higher harmonics of the deflection waveform you wish to display.

about.label: Choose higher harmonics
about.description: These comma-separated higher harmonics of the deflection waveform will be displayed.

about.label: Include time histories
about.description: To include a sample of deflection waveform, interaction history data and more, select "yes."

about.label: History based on Amp ratios?
about.description: To extract time histories at specific amplitude ratios locations, select "yes." To extract time histories at specific Z locations, select "no"

about.label: Frequency display of force?
about.description: To display the fourier transformed force and see the frequncy content select "yes". To display the force against time, select "no"

about.label: Number of time histories
about.description: Number of individual time histories to be collected.

about.label: Choose time history A or Z points
about.description: For these comma-separated values of A1/A0 or Z, as applicable, the simulation plots a sample of the deflection and tip-sample interaction histories.
about.label: Choose time history X points
about.description: For these comma-separated values of X, the simulation plots a sample of the deflection and tip-sample interaction histories.
about.label: Frequency for sample of history data
about.description: For these comma separated values of frequency, the simulation plots a sample of the deflection and tip-sample interaction histories.

about.label: Number of cycles
about.description: This is the number of complete cycles included in the sample of defelction and tip-sample interaction history.

about.label: Observed Deflection in Time History
about.description: Check to include observed deflection in the time history plot

about.label: Make plots of force versus gap
about.description: By default, the time history plot is force and gap versus time. If you click this, then you get force plotted versus gap.

about.label: Choose X-axis variable
about.description: Choose the independent variable. (Note: 1st harmonic amplitude is always plotted against Z-distance regardless of setting because plotting amplitude against itself is not too useful)

about.label: Amplitude ratio
about.description: The ratio of amplitude vs. initial (unconstrained) amplitude.

about.label: Z-distance (nm)
about.description: The approach distance.

about.label: Min gap (nm)
about.description: The minimum distance between tip and sample

about.label: 2nd Frequency Amplitude ratio (bimodal only)
about.description: The ratio of amplitude @ 2nd frequency vs. initial (unconstrained) amplitude at 2nd frequency.

about.label: Stroboscopic
about.description: Check to include a stroboscopic poincare section which displays phase-space variables at integer period intervals.

about.label: Impact
about.description: Check to include a impact poincare section which displays phase-space variables at contact initialization times.

about.label: Number of Poincare plots
about.description: The number of unique Poincare plots to be generated.

about.label: X-axis
about.description: Enter comma separated values for the state-space variables to be plotted on the horizontal axis. Enter 0 for d (tip-sample gap), -1 for time, -2 for Z, or 2*n-1 for deflection in mode n

about.label: Y-axis
about.description: Enter comma separated values for the state-space variables to be plotted on the vertical axis. Enter 0 for d(d)/dt (tip velocity), 2*n-2 for deflection in mode n, or 2*n for velocity of mode n

about.label: Fourier
about.description: Check to include the fourier integral plots for amplitude and phase (if unchecked, then only the lock-in values are plotted).

about.label: A_RMS
about.description: Check to include the RMS amplitude plot.

about.label: A_1,1
about.description: Check to include the first harmonic amplitude plot.

about.label: A_1,2
about.description: Check to include the second frequency amplitude plot.

about.label: Phase_1,1
about.description: Check to include the first harmonic phase vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: Phase_1,2
about.description: Check to include the second frequency phase plot.

about.label: Mean interaction force
about.description: Check to include the mean interaction force vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: Peak interaction forces
about.description: Check to include the peak interaction forces vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: Energy dissipated
about.description: Check to include the engergy dissipated per cycle vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: Energy plots in eV/drive cycle?
about.description: Check to plot energy units as eV/drive cycle (default). Uncheck for pW.

about.label: Energy propagation
about.description: Check to include the engergy propagation terms cycle vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: Ancykowski formula
about.description: Check to caclulate Ancykowski's formula for tip-sample dissipation (for comparison ONLY! May be inaccurate in many situations, especially in liquids. For the true energy disspation, use the 'Energy Dissipated' checkbox above)

about.label: Tip-sample virial (numerical)
about.description: Check to numerically integrate tip-sample virial

about.label: Indentation
about.description: Check to include the indentation vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: Contact time
about.description: Check to include the contact time vs. the selected x-axis variable.

about.label: 1st Harmonic of interaction force
about.description: Check to include the 1st harmonic amplitude of the tip-sample interaction force.
